results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: Was It Really a Hot Zone Summer?
results.abstract: From Covid to dengue, viral outbreaks seemed to be popping up all over. But maybe Americans are just more attuned to threats now.

multimedia.caption: Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.
multimedia.copyright: Jon Cherry/Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.
multimedia.copyright: Jon Cherry/Getty Images

results.title: The World Is a Mess. That Makes the Climate Crisis Harder to Solve.
results.abstract: A transformed China, conflicts in Ukraine and elsewhere, and intractable clashes over money have pushed the prospects of progress to a new low.
results.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Max Bearak
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: The United Nations headquarters in Manhattan, where the General Assembly begins on Monday.

results.title: They’ve Got a Plan to Fight Global Warming. It Could Alter the Oceans.
results.abstract: By tweaking the chemistry of rivers and oceans, humans could remove billions of tons of carbon dioxide from the air. But huge challenges loom.
results.byline: By Brad Plumer, Raymond Zhong and Greta Rybus

multimedia.copyright: Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times

results.title: Earth’s Fall Equinox Ushers In Astronomical Autumn
results.abstract: During an equinox, places around the globe experience nearly equal amounts of daytime and nighttime. The second occurrence this year happens on Sunday.

multimedia.caption: Equinoxes occur when Earth reaches a point in its orbit where the sun shines directly on the Equator, occurring twice each year, in March and September
multimedia.copyright: NASA

multimedia.caption: Equinoxes occur when Earth reaches a point in its orbit where the sun shines directly on the Equator, occurring twice each year, in March and September
multimedia.copyright: NASA

results.title: Drug Overdose Deaths Are Dropping. The Reasons Are Not Perfectly Clear.
results.abstract: The decrease across the country is a major breakthrough in efforts to reverse the effects of fentanyl. Researchers and health officials say there is no easy explanation for the trend.

multimedia.caption: Data suggests that some of the tools used to combat opioid overdoses, like the overdose-reversing medication Narcan, were having a significant impact.
multimedia.copyright: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Data suggests that some of the tools used to combat opioid overdoses, like the overdose-reversing medication Narcan, were having a significant impact.

results.title: What We Know (and Don’t Know) About ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Food
results.abstract: There’s a growing understanding of the health threats of PFAS chemicals in what we eat and drink.

multimedia.caption: PFAS-contaminated beef from a farm in Maine.

results.title: Her Children Were Sick. Was It ‘Forever Chemicals’ on the Family Farm?
results.abstract: Pastures were fertilized with toxic sewage decades ago. Nobody knew, until the cows’ milk was tested.

multimedia.copyright: Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times
Greta Rybus for The New York Times

results.title: Michel Siffre, 85, Dies; Descended Into Caves to Study the Human Mind
results.abstract: He was a pioneer in chronobiology, the study of how our bodies understand the passage of time.

multimedia.caption: Michel Siffre waved to well-wishers before beginning a two-month sojourn in the Clamouse cave in France in November 1999.
multimedia.copyright: Philippe Desmazes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Nasal Flu Vaccine Is Approved for At-Home Use
results.abstract: The F.D.A. authorized AstraZeneca’s treatment to be given outside a health care setting, although it will still need a prescription.

multimedia.caption: The FluMist vaccine will remain available from prescribers as an in-office treatment.

results.title: F.T.C. Accuses Drug Middlemen of Inflating Insulin Prices
results.abstract: The case takes aim at the major pharmacy benefit managers, agency officials said, claiming that they favored more expensive insulin products and forced patients to pay more.
results.byline: By Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins

multimedia.caption: Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission.

results.title: Three Mile Island Plans to Reopen as Demand for Nuclear Power Grows
results.abstract: The infamous plant, closed since 2019, is getting a new lease on life after Microsoft agreed to buy its electricity to supply a growing fleet of data centers.

multimedia.caption: The Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Londonderry Township, Pa.
multimedia.copyright: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: John A. Clements Dies at 101; His Research Saved Thousands of Babies
results.abstract: He identified the cause of a respiratory condition that was killing 10,000 infants a year in the United States. Then he helped design a drug that slashed those mortality rates.

multimedia.caption: Dr. John A. Clements in 2016. His pulmonary research led to a treatment for respiratory distress syndrome, or R.D.S., once the leading cause of neonatal deaths in the United States.
multimedia.copyright: Steve Babuljak, via UCSF

multimedia.caption: Dr. John A. Clements in 2016. His pulmonary research led to a treatment for respiratory distress syndrome, or R.D.S., once the leading cause of neonatal deaths in the United States.
multimedia.copyright: Steve Babuljak, via UCSF

results.title: Prehistoric Earth Was Very Hot. That Offers Clues About Future Earth.
results.abstract: At times during the past half-billion years, carbon dioxide warmed our planet more than previously thought, according to a new reconstruction of Earth’s deep past.

multimedia.caption: An artist’s impression of life on Earth during the Carboniferous Period, 300 million years ago.
multimedia.copyright: Felix Images/Alamy

results.title: Asphalt Schoolyards Get a Shady Makeover
results.abstract: Schools across the country are adding trees, tent-like structures and water to their playgrounds as temperatures soar.

results.title: Research That Led to Obesity Drugs Wins Major Medical Prize
results.abstract: Three scientists were recognized by the Lasker Awards for their work on the GLP-1 hormone. Others were honored for work to stop H.I.V. and for immune system discoveries.
results.byline: By Gina Kolata and Stephanie Nolen

multimedia.caption: Svetlana Mojsov is one of several scientists recognized by the Lasker Foundation whose work helped pave the way for blockbuster obesity and diabetes drugs.
multimedia.copyright: Chris Taggart/The Rockefeller University, via Lasker Foundation

multimedia.caption: Svetlana Mojsov is one of several scientists recognized by the Lasker Foundation whose work helped pave the way for blockbuster obesity and diabetes drugs.

results.title: ‘Red Flags’ on Climate: U.S. Methane Emissions Keep Climbing
results.abstract: Satellite data shows the U.S. releasing more and more of the potent greenhouse gas into the atmosphere, researchers said, despite pledges to cut back.

multimedia.caption: The concentration of methane in the atmosphere is now more than two-and-a-half times greater than preindustrial levels.
multimedia.copyright: David Goldman/Associated Press

multimedia.caption: The concentration of methane in the atmosphere is now more than two-and-a-half times greater than preindustrial levels.

results.title: Tyson Faces Lawsuit Over Labeling of ‘Climate-Smart’ Beef
results.abstract: An environmental group said the company, a major food producer, was misleading shoppers with its claims about eco-friendly practices.

multimedia.caption: Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”
Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”
Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”

results.title: Floods Wreak Havoc Across Four Continents
results.abstract: Flooding events around the world share a common factor of an atmosphere made warmer by climate change. What can be done to help citizens prepare?
results.byline: By Austyn Gaffney and Somini Sengupta

multimedia.caption: The swollen Elbe river in Dresden, Germany, on Tuesday.

results.title: Bulletproofing America’s Classrooms
results.abstract: Ballistic armor companies are marketing protective products designed for the military to parents and schools. Some people see the items as unsettling but prudent; others find them infuriating.
results.byline: By Emily Baumgaertner and Alex Kalman

multimedia.copyright: The New York Times
The New York Times
The New York Times

results.title: Study Reveals Bird-Migration Mystery
results.abstract: By outfitting blackbirds with heart-rate monitors, scientists debunked a long-held assumption about the benefits of spending the winter in warm climates.

multimedia.copyright: Christian Ziegler/Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior
Christian Ziegler/Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior
Christian Ziegler/Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior

results.title: What R.F.K. Jr.’s Alliance With Trump Could Mean for Public Health
results.abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has long voiced doubts about vaccine safety, has hopes of influencing federal health policy. Could he finally get the chance?

multimedia.caption: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. speaking at a rally in May. Donald Trump has said that he “probably would” appoint Mr. Kennedy to a role in his administration.
multimedia.copyright: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times

results.title: How Colorado Cowboys and Conservationists Joined Forces to Stop Drilling
results.abstract: The members of a self-described ragtag group had little in common, but their campaign could serve as model for future environmental efforts.
results.byline: By Zoë Rom and Eli Imadali

results.title: Plastic Waste and Toxic Sludge: A Sweep of a Messy Beat
results.abstract: The Climate reporter Hiroko Tabuchi is interested in all the things we take for granted about our environment.

results.title: Deep Links Between Alcohol and Cancer Are Described in New Report
results.abstract: Scientists continue to rethink the idea that moderate drinking offers health benefits.

multimedia.caption: Excessive alcohol consumption increases the risk of six different types of cancer, but consumers are generally unaware.
multimedia.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
